node.title: Non-alcoholic drinks are taking up more space on the bottle shop shelf, but do they taste any good?
node.alt: glass of beer sitting on a table in a pub
node.description: Health-conscious consumers are voting with their feet (and taste buds) as non-alcoholic drinks get closer to the real deal.
node.content:
["Growth in non-alcoholic drinks is soaring as consumers seek\u00a0alternatives that look, smell and taste like the real deal.", "Traditionally non-alcoholic beverages are a niche product\u00a0\u2014 \u00a0they make up less than one per cent of the market.", "And beverages that loved\u00a0your liver often left the taste buds wanting.", "But this is changing fast, according to\u00a0Malcom Eadie, the Brand Director of international drinks company\u00a0Lion.", "In the past 12 months the market share of\u00a0non-alcoholic beer grew by 101 per cent.\u00a0", "\"Growth in the last couple of years has been exceptional,\" he said.", "\"It's about being able to give consumers products that meets their needs today and this ... will continue\u00a0to grow over the short, medium and long term.\"", "The industry is keen to jump on the bandwagon.", "This year Lion imported a $6 million dollar zero-alcohol plant from Germany and in September released the James Squire 'Zero' beer.", "Mr Eadie said\u00a0initial consumer sentiment towards the new product had been positive.", "\"I think people are loving the fact that... the taste is there,\" he said.\u00a0", "", "
According to Brand Director of Lion, Malcom Eadie, non-alcoholic drinks are gaining popularity with health-conscious consumers looking to moderate.(Supplied: Malcom Eadie)
", "
More than beer-able
", "But non-alcohol beers aren't new, so why all the fuss?", "What's different, according to Owen Johnston, the Head of Sales and Marketing at Hop Products Australia, is quality.", "\"That's one of the most important changes in the recent evolution of non-alcohol beers \u2014 they are \u2026 much closer to the understanding of what beer should be,\" he said.", "He says previous products were too sweet and too simple; more of a malt drink than a fair dinkum beer, partly because they often lacked hops.", "", "
Owen Johnston believes the addition of hops to non-alcoholic beers has improved the flavour profiles available to consumers(ABC Rural: David Barnott-Clement)
", "\"For me they were \u2026 out of balance, they were missing some of those pillars that makes beer, beer.\"", "With consumers voting with their feet, and their taste buds, he says you can expect to see a more diverse range of higher quality products.", "\"Brewers will seek to differentiate their product through unique flavours \u2026 just like in the alcohol space.\"\u00a0", "
Getting into the spirit of things
", "Ruby Daly runs Hellfire Bluff Distillery in southern Tasmania and has just released her first non-alcoholic offering, Inspirit.", "\"It's basically a gin alternative for people who are choosing not to drink,\" Ms Daly said.", "\"We have a lot of people come and visit our brand and for many different reasons they can't drink, so I wanted to make sure \u2026 that they're included in our range.\"", "", "
Ruby Daly says to stay current in a competitive market she has expanded into the non-alcoholic sector(ABC Rural: David Barnott-Clement)
", "The product hit the shelves four months ago and Ms Daly says sales are soaring, particularly in the Sydney market.", "But the product is not without its challenges.", "Dr Hazel MacTavish West is a food technologist who helped develop\u00a0the recipe for Inspirit.", "She says unlike other spirits it has a shelf life, so contains preservatives and allergens. And making the main ingredient \u2013 water \u2013 react with botanicals the same way gin does is complicated.", "\"It's actually a lot more difficult than you would think,\" she said.", "\"Alcohol extracts different things from the plant material than if you just soak them in water, so that's the biggest challenge.\"", "", "
Creating a non-alcoholic spirit in a conventional distillery needed a complete change in mindset for the people at Hellfire Bluff.(ABC Rural: David Barnott-Clement)
", "
This is grape!
", "Of all non-alcoholic beverages, drinks writer Max Allen believes wine is the hardest to remove alcohol from while achieving the same result.", "\"Wine has been the one that has been very, very difficult to achieve products that are as good as their alcoholic counterparts, but that is really beginning to happen now and you're beginning to see growth in all categories,\" Mr Allen said.", "Like many people Mr Allen was sceptical about the early non-alcoholic wines because he didn't get the same drinking satisfaction, but the development of the category has changed his mind.", "\"I think people are taking a lot more time and effort and spending more money and trying new techniques because ...\u00a0the market is growing at such a rate.\"", "Between 2015 and 2020 the global non- and low-alcohol wine category grew by 25 per cent, and the growth rate forecast for the next five years by drink market analysts IWSR was 15 per cent per year on average, compared to less than one per cent per year for total wine volume.", "But non-alcohol wines still only account for less than half of one per cent of total wine consumption.", "Australian company Edenvale Wine began producing non-alcohol wine in 2006 and in that time founder Michael Bright has seen the category evolve dramatically.", "\"I think the technology has come ahead in leaps and bounds now, in Australia we're producing some really good quality non-alcoholic wines,\" Mr Bright said.", "When the company started out they were de-alcoholising the wine at temperatures up in the high 60 degrees Celsius.", "\"Obviously the heat has a real impact on the varietal characteristics but now we've got temperatures down into the low 30s and this allows us to do a much greater diversity of wines.\""]
